data.text:
Ages ago I made a brief reference to the Brazilian culinary delight, â€˜pÃ£o de queijoâ€™, or â€˜cheese breadâ€™, in a post about pronunciation.

I would say itâ€™s pronounced, more or less, â€œPUWNG jee KAY-zhooâ€, but watch out for the â€œpuwngâ€ as you could end up inadvertently asking for something different. Whatever way you say it, itâ€™s not â€œpowâ€. See â€˜Brazilian Portuguese: Pronunciation Tips for Beginnersâ€™ for why.

Pronunciation aside, pÃ£o de queijo deserves a blog post in its own right since itâ€™s a very popular savoury snack among Brazilians, and to be in Brazil and not know what it is a blunder akin to not knowing what aÃ§aÃ­ is or never having tried a caipirinha.

But you canâ€™t spend long in Brazil without stumbling upon some pÃ£o de queijo at some point â€“ itâ€™s sold all over the place: restaurants; cafÃ©s; street stalls; snack bars in bus stations and airports; beach â€˜quiosquesâ€™ (â€˜kiosksâ€™ â€“ pronounced â€œki-OS-kisâ€, haha!); supermarketsâ€¦ Basically itâ€™s everywhere.

The popular chain, â€˜Casa do PÃ£o de Queijoâ€™, can be spotted in all major cities and many smaller ones, though in my personal opinion pÃ£o de queijo is just as delightful at other establishments and often significantly cheaper.

The usual pÃ£o de queijo is simply a mini, round bread roll â€“ around 4-5 cm in diameter â€“ made with cassava or tapioca flour with tasty cheese inside, and it is especially delicious when still warm as the cheese inside is nice and chewy. The type of cheese varies but is usually very mild, often with parmesan or â€œrequeijÃ£oâ€ (pronounced, more or less: â€˜heh-keh-ZHAOWNGâ€™, or somesuch thatâ€™s hard to write phonetically), which is sort of a cross between spreadable butter and cream cheese. However, being British, I prefer to have pÃ£o de queijo with cheddar, as offered on the â€˜Casa do PÃ£o de Queijoâ€™ menu.

Although I described pÃ£o de queijo as a savoury snack itâ€™s possible to chow down on a tasty sweet version too â€“ with one of my favourite sweet treats: doce de leite (pronounced, more or less: â€œDO-say jee LAY-cheeâ€) â€“ milk sweetened with sugar, boiled until concentrated into a creamy spread or into something resembling fudge.

Yum.

For the adventurous among you â€“ or those that have more culinary skills than me (which will be most of you) â€“ you can try to make them yourself at home.

Check out these websites for recipes:

http://www.simplyrecipes.com/recipes/easy_brazilian_cheese_bread/

http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/member/views/PAO-DE-QUEIJO-AKA-BRAZILIAN-CHEESE-PUFFS-1266023

One of these delicious little snacks is by no means enough, so usually you will order 5, or 8, or 12, or however itâ€™s offered at your establishment of choice.

PÃ£o de queijo: Great as a snack and great for sharing. Just great in general.

Enjoy! ğŸ™‚
